Posts.Content: May 2, 2009 04:03PM VisaliaMom wrote: I had more fatigue with chemo, which went from 6/12/08 to 11/20/08, than I did with radiation.  I had very little fatigue during radiation.  I had four weeks rest between chemo and radiation therapy.  I had 31 tx + 5 boosts of rads that ended 2/13/09.  I worked 8-hours days during my rad treatments. Also agree with Nelia48 to keep using the creams.  I used the pure aloe vera gel and the aquafor, but at one point the skin started to break.  Then I was prescribed a generic for Silvadene, which worked amazingly. The onc rad nurse said it's a topical antibiotic cream.  My skin was totally healed within a week from the last treatment.  The skin and scar is beautifully smooth and tanned! : )

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2009 05:25AM VisaliaMom wrote: I finished 28 rads + 5 boosts on 2/13/09.  This week I started feeling a tightness just where the radiation "tan" is.  (A bolus, which was rectangular in shape, was placed on my chest during rads.  So I have a rectangle tan.)  With the tightness are the pin-prick pains and a burning sensation along the center of my chest by the sternum.  If it doesn't get better, I'll see my doctor. I have read in other posts that some have been told by their doctors that the tightness is caused by scar tissue holding the skin to the underlying connective tissue.  They were referred to a certified lymphedema therapist to learn massages to break up the connection so the skin can move freely.  Under this same forum, there is a topic,"Skin Tightening After Chest Rads." Binney4's 4/2/09 post recommends that an LE therapist be seen to rule out the beginning of lymphedema.  There is more good information there.  Thank you to all who share what you have learned so we can be better informed!

Posts.Content: May 13, 2009 12:47AM - edited May 13, 2009 12:48AM by VisaliaMom Hi, Krissy~ I have the same problem as you.  Because I had a little bit of swelling under my arm (I also have lymphedema) I saw my lymphedema therapist.  I told her about the tightness in the chest too.  She said that scar tissue is adhering to connective tissue under the skin.  This makes the skin not want to "give" when we stretch or lift our arm. Many times this is caused by the radiation therapy.  She has been massaging the chest area.  Some areas of the skin have broken away from the scar tissue so it is moving easier, but there are some areas, particulary along the side of the ribcage that is a little more difficult to loosen. She also gave me some stretching exercises to help keep the skin loose.  The swelling was caused by the tighteness of skin.  It was making it more difficult for the lymphatic fluid to flow so it was backing up a little.  I would recommend you see your onc for a recommendation to a certified lymphedema therapist.  I don't know if a physical therapist would be able to help--maybe if they knew how to work with breast cancer problems
